name: Equine-Assisted Therapy (EAT/EAP/Hippotherapy)
summary: Therapeutic interventions that incorporate horses to address physical, emotional, cognitive, and social goals. Includes psychotherapy with horses (EAP), therapeutic riding, and hippotherapy delivered by licensed rehab clinicians.
description: Equine-assisted therapy is an umbrella term for structured, goal-directed services involving horses. Mental-health–focused models (often called Equine-Assisted Psychotherapy, EAP) use groundwork and sometimes mounted activities to facilitate insight, emotion regulation, and interpersonal skills. Skill- and recreation-focused programs (therapeutic riding/equestrian activities) aim to build confidence, social skills, and functional abilities. In rehabilitation, hippotherapy is a clinical treatment in which physical, occupational, or speech therapists use the horse’s movement as part of a plan of care to influence posture, balance, sensorimotor processing, and communication. Evidence suggests benefits for balance and gross motor function in select neurologic conditions (especially children with cerebral palsy) and promising—though mixed—findings for PTSD, anxiety, and autism spectrum–related outcomes.

practice_styles: Therapeutic riding / equestrian activities for therapy
treatment_variants: Group-based resilience or trauma programs (e.g., veterans)
delivery_methods: In-person sessions at accredited equine centers
1:1 or small-group formats with horse handler and clinician
Helmet and adaptive tack for mounted work
metadata.invasiveness_level: Non-invasive (physical risk inherent to equestrian activity)
metadata.session_duration: 45–60 minutes (30–45 minutes for young children or rehab focus)
treatment_duration: Ongoing programs for chronic/ developmental needs
metadata.training_required: EAP delivered by licensed mental health professionals with equine specialization; hippotherapy delivered by licensed PT/OT/SLP with formal hippotherapy training; therapeutic riding by certified instructors (e.g., PATH Intl.).
metadata.regulatory_status: Program accreditation and instructor certification available (e.g., PATH Intl., AHA). Licensure tied to the clinician’s profession for psychotherapy/rehab.

primary_indications: Balance and postural control deficits (e.g., cerebral palsy)
conditions_treated: Autism spectrum disorder and ADHD (social-emotional skills)
contraindications: Absolute: Unstable cervical spine or severe osteoporosis; uncontrolled seizures; severe allergy to horses/barn environment; active psychosis compromising safety.
Relative: Severe scoliosis/hip instability, recent orthopedic surgery, severe behavioral dysregulation/violence risk, severe asthma triggered by barn allergens.
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally well tolerated in accredited programs; risks include falls, bites/kicks, allergic/asthma flares, and musculoskeletal strain. Helmets, trained horses, side-walkers, and emergency protocols mitigate risk.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate for balance/gross motor function in pediatric cerebral palsy; low-to-moderate and heterogeneous for PTSD/anxiety and autism-related outcomes; limited for other conditions.

sections.text: Mounted work provides multidimensional, rhythmic movement analogous to human pelvic motion during gait, offering intensive sensorimotor input that can improve postural control, balance, and coordination (hippotherapy). In psychotherapeutic models, the horse’s size, responsiveness, and nonjudgmental presence facilitate attunement, emotion regulation, experiential learning, and relational skills. Additional factors include novelty, mastery experiences, and structured, co-regulated tasks.

sections.preparation: Clinical assessment, goal-setting, and medical screening; informed consent; fit helmet and adaptive equipment.
procedure: Groundwork (grooming, leading, obstacle navigation) to build rapport and skills.
Mounted activities targeting posture, balance, and coordination (with side-walkers/lead as needed).
Psychotherapy sessions integrate equine tasks with evidence-based modalities (e.g., CBT, trauma-focused work).
Cool-down, debrief, and documentation of goal progress.

short_term: Improved social communication or adaptive behaviors
long_term: Sustained gains in motor function for CP (with ongoing therapy)

absolute: Severe osteoporosis or recent fragility fracture
Severe behavioral dysregulation posing safety risk
special_considerations: Helmet use for all mounted sessions; use side-walkers and emergency plans.
Veterans with PTSD may benefit from gradual exposure and clear boundaries.
Ensure horse welfare (workload limits, rest, veterinary care) and ethical practices.

ideal_candidates: Children with CP needing dynamic postural training
Veterans or trauma survivors seeking experiential therapies
Autistic individuals who respond to structured, sensory-friendly activity
Adults in neurorehab needing engagement for balance/mobility
screening_required: Medical clearance for mounted activity when indicated
Musculoskeletal and neurologic assessment (ROM, spine/hip stability)

concurrent_therapies: Social skills groups and parent training

sections.typical_session_cost: $75–$200 per session (varies by model and staffing)
sections.total_treatment_cost: 8–16+ sessions; scholarships often available via non-profits
sections.insurance_coverage: Hippotherapy may be reimbursed when billed as PT/OT/SLP; EAP/therapeutic riding less commonly covered

items: Use accredited centers (e.g., PATH Intl.) and licensed clinicians for clinical models.
Document objective goals (e.g., GMFM for CP; PCL-5 or GAD-7 for PTSD/anxiety).
Balance client benefit with horse welfare and ethical considerations.
Evidence base strongest for pediatric CP motor outcomes; mental health findings promising but heterogeneous.
